comments.comment: Hi! thanks for your contribution!, great first issue!

As per the XLA troubleshooting guide:
Tensor shapes should be the same between iterations, or a low number of shape variations should be used.
In this application the images shapes are different for each batch. Could that be the issue?

Seems like there's an issue while trying to save the hyperparams. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rohitgr7>@rohitgr7</denchmark-link> any idea about this? Also I am unable to run the entire notebook as the data is present in Google Drive.
yeah maybe, if either we can somehow get the data or just input data shape, maybe we can reproduce this and check the real issue here.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/rohitgr7>@rohitgr7</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/lezwon>@lezwon</denchmark-link> Images are of different shape ranging form a few pixels to 65k pixels per channel. The images are padded in a batch to make them of an equal shape. So, the batch shapes would differ.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/ishgirwan>@ishgirwan</denchmark-link> mind trying by excluding the model from saving in hyperparameters? just call instead of .

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/lezwon>@lezwon</denchmark-link> It seems to be working. But I got this error. It may be a RAM issue as the model was training for some time for a batch size of 8 on Colab(15GB). I am new to TPUs so how should I manage the batch size wrt the number of cores? I think the model could not be parsed to yaml, as showing in the error. Probably avoid storing complex objects like models within hyperparams. :) Also to debug the above error, I'll need access to the notebook with the data. It's very hard to guess what might be going wrong without having a reproducible notebook.
Thanks :) Can we connect on the pytorch lightning slack channel? I can dm you the details over there.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/ishgirwan>@ishgirwan</denchmark-link> I had a look at the notebook. I strongly suspect colab runs out of memory during the training, due to the dynamic size of your inputs. XLA will compile a new graph for every example if it has a different size than the others. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/pytorch/xla/issues/2383#issuecomment-666849249>Reference</denchmark-link> . Try padding your inputs to maintain a consistent size. Let me know if that works.

Also I dont think this optimizer_step function needs to be defined. Lightning handles this behind the scenes and calls xm.optimizer_step(optimizer) when training on TPU's. üëç <denchmark-code>def optimizer_step(self, current_epoch, batch_idx, optimizer, optimizer_idx, second_order_closure=None, on_tpu=False, using_native_amp=False, using_lbfgs=False): optimizer.step() </denchmark-code>

Thanks a lot <denchmark-link:https://github.com/lezwon>@lezwon</denchmark-link> for looking into this issue. As you mentioned, the issue is probably with the way XLA functions, since the code has worked properly with GPU. Padding would work as the images will then be of equal size. I will close this issue now. Also, I have hosted the dataset at <denchmark-link:https://www.kaggle.com/ishgirwan/predict-hdi-of-villages-using-satellite-imagery>Kaggle</denchmark-link> . Thanks again.
